Title:
Multi-gene differences between Microdochium nivale and M.
majus
Keywords:
Microdochium nivale; Microdochium majus; plant disease;
pink snow mold; Fusarium patch; Microdochium patch
Abstract:
Microdochium nivale and M. majus are sister species that
cause diseases on grasses and cereals at low temperatures. The sequences
of four genetic regions from these groups were analysed to compare the
extent of differences between these species; between isolates that were
collected from Europe compared to those from North America; and between
isolates of M. nivale originally collected from Agrostis spp. compared
to isolates collected on wheat (Triticum aestivum). The four regions
studied were RPB2 (RNA polymerase II), β-tubulin, EF-1α (elongation
factor), and ITS (rDNA internal transcribed spacer). All of the regions
studied except for ITS resolved the M. nivale and M. majus isolates into
separate clades. The RPB2 sequences also resolved both the North
American and European M.majus isolates and M. nivale isolates from
either turfgrasses or wheat into separate clades. These results support
the recent elevation of M. nivale and M. majus to sister species, and
also provide some support for the assertion that there may be
host-specific differences among M. nivale, which has a wider host range
than M. majus.
